content.content: CPR consists of pushing on the chest (compressions) and providing positive pressure ventilations (breaths) to circulate oxygenated blood to all vital organs, including the brain.

When there are no signs of life. In addition to a palpable pulse, signs of life include chest rise, movement of any kind, and good skin color (pink skin or mucous membranes). If you witness a collapse and notice unresponsiveness, and you're in an urban setting, activate the EMS system (call 911) and use an AED, if available, before beginning compressions.
When should CPR be stopped in an urban setting?

items: When someone relieves you that is trained in CPR
An EMS professional relieves you
If you are exhausted
If you are in danger (e.g., environmental factors, traffic, violent bystanders etc…)
If you resuscitate the person
When an authorized medical professional declares the person dead

rows: 1 finger width below the nipple line

items: 1. Ask the person if they are choking.
2. If yes:
• Stand behind the conscious person and wrap your arms around their waist, under their rib cage.
• Put the side of your fist (thumb side) one finger-width above the person's navel in the middle of their belly. Do not press on the lower part of the sternum.
• With your other hand, grasp the fist and pull the clenched fist sharply and directly backward and upward under the rib cage 6 to 10 times quickly, (in a "J" motion).
• Continue performing these thrusts until the obstruction is relieved or until the person becomes unresponsive.

content.content: When a person becomes unresponsive call 911. If you are the only rescuer with a child, attempt to dislodge the object, and then call 911.

items: 1. Open airway — remove object if you can see it.
2. (No abdominal thrusts!) Start CPR with this extra step—each time you open the airway look for object in the back of the throat. Remove object if visible. If not, continue CPR.
3. Once dislodged — CAB!
1. Perform 5 back slaps and 5 chest thrusts until object is dislodged or infant becomes unresponsive.

content.content: If you are the only rescuer with a child, attempt to dislodge object for about 2 minutes, then call 911.

items: 1. Place infant on flat surface
2. Open airway — remove object if you can see it.
3. Start CPR with one extra step — each time you open the airway look for object in the back of the throat.
4. Once dislodged — CAB!

content.content: An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device that automatically diagnoses life threatening cardiac arrhythmias in the heart. If needed, it can send an electric shock to the heart to try to restore a normal rhythm. AEDs are used to treat sudden cardiac arrest.
The American Heart Association suggests that early defibrillation is critical for victims of sudden cardiac arrest for the following reasons:

items: 1. The most common initial rhythm during cardiac arrest is ventricular fibrillation (v-fib). In v-fib the heart quivers and does not pump blood. Another unsustainable rhythm is ventricular tachycardia (v-tach).

2. V-fib & v-tach deteriorate quickly into asystole (flat line) if not treated. AEDs are computerized devices that are attached to a pulseless adult or child with adhesive pads. The AED will analyze the heart rhythm and advise shock delivery for ventricular fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia only.

content.content: In an urban environment, when a cardiac arrest is unwitnessed, perform 2 minutes of CPR prior to attaching the AED.

items: 1. Power on the AED
2. Attach electrodes to victim's bare chest
3. Clear the victim (stop CPR) to let machine analyze
4. If shock is advised (start compressions until AED is done charging)
5. Stop compressions and clear victim from others before shocking
6. After the first shock, follow-up with 2 minutes of CPR
7. After subsequent shocks, continue CPR when indicated by an absent carotid pulse

content.content: Airway adjuncts are usually a curved piece of plastic inserted in either the mouth (oro-) or the nose (naso-) to create an air passageway between the mouth and the posterior pharyngeal wall. They are useful when the tongue and/or epiglottis fall(s) back against the posterior pharynx in an unresponsive patient, obstructing the flow of air to the lungs.

For the oropharyngeal (OPA), the preferred technique is to use a tongue blade to depress the tongue and then insert the airway posteriorly. An alternate technique is to insert the device sideways, starting at the corner of the mouth until you reach the soft palate. Be sure not to use the OPA to push the tongue backward and block, rather than clear, the airway. Once you feel a slight resistance rotate the OPA 90 degrees, and insert until the flange reaches the teeth.

The nasopharyngeal (NPA) should be lubed with a water soluble lubricant or water before insertion. Next, using the right nostril, place the NPA with the bevel towards the septum and gently advance until the flange rests on the nostril.

5. Understand how OPAs and NPAs work and what patients get airway adjuncts.
